text: Captain Edward Calcott Pryce CBE (1885 - 20 October 1972), was a British Solicitor and Liberal Party politician. ==Background== Pryce was the son of David Pryce, of Guilsfield. He was educated at Welshpool and Aberystwyth. In 1911 he married Sylvia Middleton of Arbroath, Scotland. He was awarded the OBE in 1940 and the CBE in 1957.‘PRYCE, Edward Calcott’, Who Was Who, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2016; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2014 ; online edn, April 2014 accessed 29 July 2016 ==Professional career== Pryce qualified as a solicitor in 1909. He served in the European War of 1914–18, and the War of 1939–45. In 1954 he was appointed the Sheriff, of the City of London. In 1956 he was appointed the High Sheriff of Montgomeryshire.‘PRYCE, Edward Calcott’, Who Was Who, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2016; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2014 ; online edn, April 2014 accessed 29 July 2016 ==Political career== Pryce unsuccessfully contested the 1910 London County Council election as a Progressive Party candidate in Hackney North."London County Council Election." Times [London, England] 7 Mar. 1910 He was National Liberal candidate for the Ludlow division of Shropshire at the 1922 General Election. After that election, when the 1923 Ludlow by-election occurred, following the mood around the country, the National Liberals and Liberals in Ludlow united behind his candidature and he ran as a united Liberal candidate. Although he finished a strong second, he did not run for election again.British Parliamentary Election Results 1918-1949, FWS Craig ===Electoral record=== ==References== Category:1885 births Category:1972 deaths Category:Liberal Party (UK) parliamentary candidates Category:British Army personnel of World War I Category:British Army personnel of World War II Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire Category:Royal Field Artillery officers Category:Welsh solicitors
title: Edward Calcott Pryce
